div.p: This paper is devoted to design adaptive sliding-mode controllers for the Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy system with mismatched uncertainties and exogenous disturbances. The uncertainties in state matrices are mismatched and norm-bounded, while the exogenous disturbances are assumed to be bounded with an unknown bound, which is estimated by a simple and effective adaptive approach. Both state-and static-output-feedback slidingmode-control problems are considered. In terms of linear-matrix inequalities (LMIs), both sliding surfaces and sliding-mode controllers can be easily obtained via a convex optimization technique. Finally, two simulation examples and a real experiment are utilized to illustrate the applicability and effectiveness of the design procedures proposed in this paper.

study on T-S fuzzy systems has gained much attention in the past decades, and great efforts have been devoted to the T-S model, aiming at both theoretical research and industrial applications. Among these references, to mention a few, stability analysis was investigated in [2], stabilizing and control strategies were proposed in [3] and [4], filter designs were reported in [5], output-feedback-control schemes were investigated in [6] and [7], the fault-detection problem was studied in [8], adaptive and robust control problems were presented in [9], and the H ∞ control problem was examined in [10]. For some of the recent results in the area of fuzzy control, see the survey paper in [11].

Although a nonlinear control system can be well approximated by a suitably selected T-S fuzzy model, it creates additional model uncertainties between them. To compensate for the uncertainties and/or disturbances, several control-system design and analysis approaches have been proposed. Among the existing robust control approaches, sliding-mode control (SMC) [12], [13] has been recognized as an effective robust control approach for uncertain systems, and it has successfully been applied to a wide variety of practical engineering systems, such as robot manipulators, aircraft, underwater vehicles, spacecraft, flexible space structures, electrical motors, power systems, and automotive engines. The main features of SMC systems are 1) fast response and good transient performance; 2) robustness against a large class of perturbations or model uncertainties; and 3) the possibility of stabilizing some complex nonlinear systems that are difficult to stabilize by continuous state-feedback laws. Because of these advantages, in the past decades, SMC, as a general design tool for robust control systems, has been well investigated; see [14]- [21] and the recent survey paper [22] and monographs [23].

Recently, a study on SMC for the T-S fuzzy system has received much attention. For instance, some excellent results on adaptive fuzzy SMC for linear systems with mismatched time-varying uncertainties were presented in [24], in which the adaptive scheme was used to reduce control chattering. Both stabilization and output-tracking problems were studied in [25] for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems by combining the T-S fuzzy-modeling method and the SMC technique. Lin et al. [26] further employed a similar approach to investigate the stabilization problem of uncertain fuzzy-time-delay systems. By means of the T-S fuzzy-modeling approach, the SMC problem for nonlinear stochastic time-delay systems with parametric uncertainties and unknown nonlinearities was investigated in [27]. More recently, some very excellent results on fuzzy sliding-mode underactuated control for autonomous dynamic balance of an electrical bicycle was reported in [28]. However, it should be pointed out that there are some limitations to the existing results. The main drawback comes from the requirement to predetermine state variables of systems; however, in practical applications, state variables are often not all available. Second, some strict assumptions were imposed on system matrix, for example, in [29], input matrix B i was supposed to be square, and r i=1 h i (θ(t))B i was assumed to be invertible, where h i (θ(t))) is the basis function; moreover, some norm inequalities were also needed in [29]. Third, parameter uncertainties in system matrix were always assumed to satisfy matching conditions (see [25] and [26]), and external disturbances were supposed to satisfy some norm condition with known nonnegative scalars. However, those scalars are not easily obtained in practice.

Motivated by the aforementioned observations, in this paper, we will organize the T-S fuzzy-model-based adaptive SMC controllers for the system under consideration. There are several important features of the developed results that are worth mentioning: 1) Information about upper bounds of mismatched uncertainties and exogenous disturbance are not required to be known but are estimated by a simple and effective adaptive approach; 2) because the state variables are often not available in practical applications, not only state feedback, but also static-output-feedback sliding-mode controllers are designed; 3) it is shown that the designs of both the sliding-surface and of the sliding-mode controller can be easily obtained via convex optimization. Finally, simulation examples and real experiment are provided to illustrate the advantage of the developed results.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: It is now well known that T-S fuzzy models can provide an effective representation of complex nonlinear systems. Therefore, in this study, the nonlinear system under consideration is represented by T-S model. As in [1], the T-S fuzzy system with norm-bounded uncertainties is described by fuzzy IF-THEN rules, which locally represent linear input-output relations of the nonlinear system. The ith rule of the T-S fuzzy model has the following form:
Plant Rule i:
div.formula: IF θ 1 (t) is M i1 , θ 2 (t) is M i2 and • • • and θ p (t) is M ip , THEN ẋ(t) = (A i + ∆A i (t))x(t) + B [u(t) + Φ(x(t), t)] (1)
div.p: where θ 1 (t), θ 2 (t), . . . , θ p (t) are premise variables, and M ij , i = 1, 2, . . . , r, j = 1, 2, . . . , p are fuzzy sets, x(t) ∈ R n is a state variable, u(t) ∈ R m is a control variable, y(t) ∈ R q is an output variable, and m < q < n. Φ(x(t), t) ∈ R m is matched uncertainty and disturbance. A i , i = 1, 2, . . . , r, B, and C are known real-constant matrices of appropriate dimensions that describe the nominal system, rank(B) = m, and rank(C) = q. ∆A i (t) is an unknown matrix representing time-varying parameter uncertainty.
By fuzzy blending, the overall fuzzy model is inferred as follows:

div.head: III. SLIDING-MODE STATE-FEEDBACK-CONTROLLER DESIGN
div.p: In this section, the design results of sliding-mode statefeedback controller will be presented. The design of SMC can be divided into two independent steps. The first step is the selection of an appropriate sliding surface, which should have the property that the desired performance can be achieved while the system state remains on the sliding surface. The next step is to organize a control law that forces the system state to reach the sliding surface in a finite amount of time and to make the sliding surface an invariant manifold.

In the following, we derive linear-matrix-inequality (LMI) conditions for the existence of a linear sliding surface guaranteeing asymptotic stability of the reduced-order sliding-mode dynamic, and we give LMI characterization of such a sliding surface. div.head: VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORKS
div.p: In this paper, we have employed the T-S fuzzy-systemmodel approach, the SMC technique, and adaptive control scheme to construct a class of robust controllers. The nonlinear system under consideration is given in the T-S forms with mismatched uncertainties and exogenous disturbance. Both stateand static-output-feedback sliding-mode controllers were designed via an adaptive control approach. In terms of LMIs, both the sliding surface and the sliding-mode controller can be easily obtained via convex optimization. Finally, two examples and a real experiment are utilized to illustrate the effectiveness of the designed procedures proposed in this paper.

There is much interesting works that lies ahead, including study of the dynamic output feedback SMC; investigation of the fuzzy sliding-mode observer-based control; application of the control scheme and theory developed in this paper to some standard industrial systems, such as 3-D overhead cranes [39], servo-pneumatic actuators, [40], solar air-conditioning systems [41], continuous-stirred tank reactors [42], servosystems [43], etc.
